object.field: This is a sample course that demonstrates the features of CSTutor.
This is a sample course that demonstrates the features of CSTutor.

To log in, select the login button on the upper right hand side.

You'll need to register before you can login.  Don't worry, we'll remember that you've joined this course after you register.

You can also log in (or simply use the site) anonymously.  Either use the site without trying to log in or explicitly checking the "anonymous" checkbox in the login screen, and you'll be able to use any public course without providing any personal information.

There are two other options that can be selected on login.

  • Remember Me: Stores your username for two weeks, even if you explicitly logout.
  • Autologin: Stores your username for two weeks, and keeps you logged in even if you leave and come back.

To log in, select the login button on the upper right hand side.

You'll need to register before you can login.  Don't worry, we'll remember that you've joined this course after you register.

You can also log in (or simply use the site) anonymously.  Either use the site without trying to log in or explicitly checking the "anonymous" checkbox in the login screen, and you'll be able to use any public course without providing any personal information.

There are two other options that can be selected on login.

  • Remember Me: Stores your username for two weeks, even if you explicitly logout.
  • Autologin: Stores your username for two weeks, and keeps you logged in even if you leave and come back.

You can edit your personal information in the profile page.  These are things like email, password, first/last name, etc.  You can also purge your account and information from our system by deleting your account.  Be careful!  That operation is irreversible.

You can edit your personal information in the profile page.  These are things like email, password, first/last name, etc.  You can also purge your account and information from our system by deleting your account.  Be careful!  That operation is irreversible.

Now that we've created a course, we should create a lesson on it.  While viewing the course landing page, select "Create lesson" from the left hand menu.  You'll be presented with the lesson creation screen (notice how it is very similar to the Course Creation screen). 

Go ahead and fill in some sample text, then go on to the next lesson.  Try creating text that is bold or underlined or superscript

Now that we've created a course, we should create a lesson on it.  While viewing the course landing page, select "Create lesson" from the left hand menu.  You'll be presented with the lesson creation screen (notice how it is very similar to the Course Creation screen). 

Go ahead and fill in some sample text, then go on to the next lesson.  Try creating text that is bold or underlined or superscript

Quizzes are significantly more complicated, so we won't provide a full description here.  The basic things you'll want to try:

  • Create a new multiple choice question.
    • Try adding a couple questions to it.
  • Create a new code question
    • Give it some text!

Quizzes are significantly more complicated, so we won't provide a full description here.  The basic things you'll want to try:

  • Create a new multiple choice question.
    • Try adding a couple questions to it.
  • Create a new code question
    • Give it some text!

Every course has a roster.  In order to view a course, you must be added to that roster.  If your course is public, join requests are added automatically.  Otherwise, the join requests are placed into a request queue, which a course manager must approve.

There are three permissions levels:

  • Edit: Can I edit the contents of the pages in this course
  • Stats: Can I view coursewide stats for this coruse
  • Manage: Can I modify the permissions of other users and approve/deny join requests

You can also add users to your course.  You'll need to know their registered username or name to  add them to your course.

Every course has a roster.  In order to view a course, you must be added to that roster.  If your course is public, join requests are added automatically.  Otherwise, the join requests are placed into a request queue, which a course manager must approve.

There are three permissions levels:

  • Edit: Can I edit the contents of the pages in this course
  • Stats: Can I view coursewide stats for this coruse
  • Manage: Can I modify the permissions of other users and approve/deny join requests

You can also add users to your course.  You'll need to know their registered username or name to  add them to your course.
You can view course stats by clicking the stats button.  Until somebody completes a quiz on your course, you won't have any stats to view.  Too bad.
You can view course stats by clicking the stats button.  Until somebody completes a quiz on your course, you won't have any stats to view.  Too bad.

Every course has a chat room, where you can converse with other users.  Click the "chat" button while viewing any course and you'll be connected to the course chat room.

NOTE: Chat rooms are unmoderated, and externally hosted.  We sincerely apologize for any abuse you receive, but we cannot control it and we are not responsible for any emotional scarring you may receive.

NOTE: Chat rooms are unmoderated, and externally hosted.  We sincerely apologize for any abuse you receive, but we cannot control it and we are not responsible for any emotional scarring you may receive.
